content: The process of appointing a Justice to the Supreme Court of the United States is outlined in the Constitution's Appointments Clause. The President nominates a candidate, who must then be confirmed by the Senate for a lifetime appointment. The most recent nomination was Merrick B. Garland by President Obama to replace Justice Scalia. Majority Leader McConnell argued that the American people should have a say in the selection of the next Justice. President Obama nominated Merrick B. Garland, a sitting judge on the U.S. Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, to replace Justice Scalia. Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Senator Chuck Grassley argued that the vacancy should not be filled until a new President is elected. Minority Leader Harry Reid and President Obama urged the Senate to consider Garland's nomination promptly. President Obama nominated Merrick B. Garland to fill the Scalia vacancy, but the Senate did not act on the nomination. President Obama urged the Senate to give Garland a fair hearing and vote. The nomination was returned to President Obama at the end of the 114th Congress. President Trump later nominated Neil M. Gorsuch to fill the vacancy, and the nomination is currently pending before the Senate. President Donald Trump nominated Neil M. Gorsuch to fill the Scalia vacancy on February 1, 2017. The nomination is currently pending before the Senate. This report analyzes the prominent issues surrounding the Scalia vacancy, including the frequency of vacancies on the Supreme Court, comparison of vacancy lengths, vacancies during presidential election years, vacancies filled by different presidencies, and multiple nominations prior to appointing a new Justice. Since President George Washington's initial six appointments to the Supreme Court in 1789 and 1790, vacancies on the Court have occurred on average every two years. In the post-War period (1946 to present), vacancies have occurred every 2.4 years, and since 1980, slightly less frequently at every 3.1 years. The time between the vacancies created by the retirement of Justice John Paul Stevens in 2010 and Justice Scalia's death in 2016 is the fifth longest period ever on the Court, at 2,054 days or 5.6 years. Justices on the Supreme Court typically hold lifetime appointments. The vacancy created by Justice Scalia's death in 2016 is the fifth longest period of time between two vacancies on the Supreme Court, lasting 2,054 days or 5.6 years. Justices on the Court typically hold lifetime appointments, often choosing to serve until they die or voluntarily step down. Over the past 225 years, 42% of vacancies have occurred due to a sitting Justice's death, while 58% have occurred for other reasons such as retirement or promotion. Since 1791, 42% of Supreme Court vacancies have been due to a sitting Justice's death, while 58% have occurred for other reasons like retirement or promotion. Over the past 60 years, only 8% of vacancies were caused by a Justice's death, with the passing of Justice Scalia in 2016 being the second instance since 1956. Prior to 1900, it was more common for vacancies to arise from a Justice's death. Since 1791, 42% of Supreme Court vacancies have been due to a sitting Justice's death. Vacancies prior to 1900 were more commonly caused by a Justice's death. On average, vacancies on the Court have lasted for 121 days before a nominee is approved by the Senate, with a range from 1 day to 835 days. The median length of time for Supreme Court vacancies is 61 days, with considerable variation ranging from 1 day to 835 days. Vacancies lasted longer before the 20th century, averaging 165 days, compared to 77 days since 1900. The Scalia vacancy has lasted 382 days, making it the seventh longest in history. The Scalia vacancy on the Supreme Court is the longest since 1861, lasting 382 days. Only one other vacancy since 1900 ranks among the top 10 longest vacancies, which occurred in 1969. The average time from nomination to final Senate action for Court nominations has been 28 days, with variations over time in the speed of Senate decisions. Since 1900, nominations for Supreme Court vacancies have seen varying wait times for final Senate action. Prior to 1900, nominations waited an average of 18 days, while since 1956, the average wait time has been 67 days. The longest pending nomination for a vacancy was Judge Garland's, lasting 293 days from March 13, 2016, to January 3, 2017. The current nomination to fill the Scalia vacancy, Judge Gorsuch, has been pending as of March 1, 2017. The nomination of Judge Garland by President Obama for the Supreme Court vacancy was the longest pending nomination since 1791, lasting 293 days. Out of 10 nominations, 6 were not approved by the Senate. The vacancy created by Justice John McLean lasted 295 days, but the nomination of Noah H. Swayne was confirmed in just 3 days. Vacancies on the Supreme Court during presidential election years are rare, with only 16 out of 111 vacancies occurring in such years. Some vacancies have multiple nominations, leading to longer periods of vacancy. For example, the vacancy created by Justice Smith Thompson lasted 424 days with six nominations totaling 190 days pending before the Senate. Since 1791, there have been a total of 9 vacancies on the Supreme Court during a presidential election year where the vacancy occurred before the general election and the President nominated someone before the election. The Scalia vacancy in 2016 was the first to occur under these circumstances since 1932. This represents 8% of all vacancies on the Court since 1791. The Scalia vacancy in 2016, along with two other vacancies in the 19th century, were not approved by the Senate for a President's nominee during a presidential election year. Since 1791, there have been nine vacancies on the Court during presidential election years where the vacancy rolled over from a preceding year, with eight of them being confirmed by the Senate during the election year itself. The Senate confirmed a nomination during a presidential election year in 1987 for Justice Powell's vacancy. In 1968, President Johnson nominated Abe Fortas and Homer Thornberry for anticipated vacancies on the Court, but the nominations were withdrawn. There have been seven vacancies on the Supreme Court filled during a different administration, prior to the Scalia vacancy. Prior to the Scalia vacancy, there have been seven Supreme Court vacancies filled during a different administration, representing approximately 6% of all vacancies filled since 1791. The last time a vacancy arose during one presidency and was filled during a different administration was in 1881. Four of these vacancies were filled by a President from a different political party than the one who left office. President Arthur succeeded his predecessor on December 20, 1881. Before the Scalia vacancy, there were seven Supreme Court vacancies filled during a different administration, with four being filled by a President from a different political party. The last time a vacancy arose during one presidency and was filled during a different administration with a new President from a different party was in 1862. During the "Second Party System" from 1828 to 1854, five Supreme Court vacancies occurred. In the "Modern Party System" from 1854 to present, eight vacancies occurred. The Scalia vacancy had the longest period of 342 days from occurrence to President Obama leaving office. Most departing Presidents nominated a replacement for vacancies during their term, except for Presidents Grant and Garfield. Six of the eight departing Presidents, including President Obama, submitted a nomination for vacancies during their presidencies. The number of days reported for each vacancy in Figure 5 does not represent the total days the vacancy existed. Sometimes, a Supreme Court vacancy is not filled after a single nomination is submitted to the Senate. Since 1791, there have been 20 vacancies on the Supreme Court that required more than one nomination before being filled. The Scalia vacancy is the most recent example of this, with 12 vacancies since 1860 needing multiple nominations before a new Justice was appointed. The Scalia vacancy is the most recent example of a Supreme Court vacancy requiring multiple nominations before being filled. Out of the 12 vacancies since 1860 that needed multiple nominations, six occurred between 1860 and 1899, one between 1900 and 1955, and five between 1956 and 2016. Six vacancies involved the Senate rejecting nominations, four involved the President withdrawing nominations, and one nominee died before taking office. The Scalia vacancy is unique as the nomination was returned to the President after the Senate took no action. The Scalia vacancy is distinctive among the 12 vacancies as the only one where a nomination was returned to the President after the Senate took no action. Vacancies requiring multiple nominations have generally lasted longer than the median length on the Court, with most lasting over 61 days and some over 100 days. Nominees eventually approved by the Senate received unanimous or nearly unanimous support at the time of confirmation. Nominees approved by the Senate typically received unanimous or nearly unanimous support at confirmation, with only a few receiving nay votes. Samuel Alito, nominated in 2006, received 42 nay votes, an exception to the usual pattern.
